title: Can the golden age of dealmaking last forever?
text:
One scoop to start: Manchester City footballer Raheem Sterling has told the FT's Murad Ahmed of his desire to leave the English Premier League champions, setting up what could be soccer's next potential blockbuster transfer.

It's still raining M&A on Wall Street

At the beginning of the month, DD asked whether things could get much better for dealmakers. The answer seems to be: probably not.

A surge in dealmaking has unleashed a windfall for investment bankers, as fees surpassed a record $100bn in the first nine months of the year. JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have all raked in a record amount in fees.

Goldman Sachs will report earnings today, but given that it holds the top spot for advisory on mergers and acquisitions, we're willing to bet its numbers will be looking good as well.

Investment banking revenues at JPMorgan rose 52 per cent to a total of $3.3bn while Morgan Stanley reported a 67 per cent rise to $2.85bn. 

At Bank of America, investment banking fees rose 23 per cent to $2.2bn and Citigroup's increased 39 per cent to $1.9bn. 

These banner results have made it difficult for any disrupters to dislodge the incumbents, according to Morgan Stanley chief James Gorman. “It's pretty hard to be a wannabe or a new entrant, trying to break into the group that is dominating,” he said on an earnings call yesterday.

But the record-high investment banking fees are covering for weaker results in other divisions.

Banks have had a drop in trading revenue, which surged in the first year of the pandemic amid extreme market volatility. There is also less demand for loans as companies are still getting through the cash they stockpiled last year to buffer the impact of the pandemic.

Citi reported a 16 per cent decline in fixed income revenue, retreating from record highs during the market turmoil over the past year, and JPMorgan said loan demand had been sluggish this year.

While things look pretty rosy now, the M&A boom isn't going to last forever.

Dealmakers are already expressing concerns about the rise in inflation, which could prompt the US government to change its fiscal policy. There's also the issue of President Joe Biden's antitrust agenda, which many see as much stricter than his predecessor's.  

At the same time, the issue of costs has emerged as a “wild card” for bank earnings this quarter after JPMorgan and BofA both raised their outlooks for expenses multiple times for this year, with JPMorgan adding that costs are likely to be higher next year too.

Expenses have continued to climb as issues surrounding burnout, mental health and attrition have sparked an expensive talent war on Wall Street.

“There's a good war for talent out there . . . and that then drives the cost when you're 60 per cent people cost,” said BofA's Brian Moynihan at a conference last month. “You've got to win the war on talent, which we do.” 

David Solomon, who visited Goldman's Manhattan headquarters throughout the pandemic (when he wasn't jetting off to the Bahamas on the company Gulfstream), is undoubtedly enjoying the ebullient back-to-work energy after another blowout quarter for M&A.

As for Dimon, we can't say the same.

Private markets: Rishi Sunak's answer to ‘levelling up' 

The UK's Rishi Sunak has identified a problem: Britain needs more investment in infrastructure, renewable energy and — apparently — technology companies.

The hedge-fund-manager-turned-UK-chancellor has also found a solution: let more pension funds pay higher fees so they can invest in private markets.

(DD isn't convinced that there's insufficient private capital in the world of tech start-ups, but let's park that issue for now.)

So-called defined contribution pension schemes, where the value of the pot is based on the amount savers contribute plus investment returns, can't invest in funds that charge annual fees of more than 0.75 per cent. This effectively rules out private equity funds with their “two and 20” model.

English local government pension schemes, which have a different model, can — and very often do — invest in private equity funds despite the fees.

British ministers are planning to consult on the idea of relaxing the cap. But as things stand, it's not clear how they'd make sure any extra cash ploughed into private equity, venture capital and infrastructure funds went into the areas they see as important to the UK government's “levelling up” agenda.

And this is if there's much extra cash to begin with. Major pensions groups such as Nest and Scottish Widows have previously said they don't want to pay higher fees. Perhaps it would be better to encourage private equity groups to cut the hefty fees than to change the rules so they can pay them, they suggest.

What a concept.

Meanwhile, private equity executives privately suggest that while “eyes would light up” in the world of private capital groups at the prospect of a new funding source, its impact on the UK economy overall could be “marginal”. 

Customer service 101 with Credit Suisse

Credit Suisse has returned with another case study on how not to deal with angry investors.

First, the Swiss bank ticked off clients facing billions of dollars of losses from its Greensill Capital-linked supply-chain finance funds with plans to charge them another $145m. Part of that is being used to prop up Greensill.

Now, the lender has come back to those same investors with a surprising proposition — the offer of complimentary investment advice and refunds on banking fees. Oh, but there's one condition: you have to be among those that have yet to begin legal proceedings against the bank.

Investors that have already launched legal action could potentially become eligible if they decide to drop their claims, a person briefed on the offer told the FT.

How tempting. Boies Schiller Flexner, which is preparing one of several class-action suits against Credit Suisse, called it a “concerning move” that had “alarmed” its clients.

The bank said clients who took advantage of the offer wouldn't be required to forgo future legal action, but would need to agree to reduce whatever they gained from litigation by the amount they were reimbursed.

Said one investor: “This seems like a too-clever way of circumventing treating all investors in the vehicles equally.”

Job moves

  • Mala Gaonkar, one of the most senior women in the hedge fund industry, plans to leave Lone Pine Capital to start a new investment firm. Gaonkar led technology, media and telecom investments as one of the $33bn firm's three portfolio managers.

  • Pinterest's co-founder and design chief Evan Sharp is stepping back from operational duties at the social media group to join Sir Jony Ive's new design company LoveFrom.

  • Bredin Prat has hired Delphine Guillotte and Yohann Chevalier as counsels on its competition and financing teams, respectively. Guillotte joins from Gide Loyrette Nouel and Chevalier returns to the firm from Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer.

  • MSD Partners has named Victor Hwang as a managing director and co-head of its new growth investment business. He was previously a senior adviser at Industry Ventures.
